The procedures address the required aspects of emergency response including:
* Proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures.
* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.
* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.
* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Galveston County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Advario continually strives to improve its safety related systems. Since the purchase of the facility Advario has been in the process of converting the operating and safety programs used by Dow Chemical over to their own standards. Advario policies and procedures provide the most efficient means to minimize environmental impacts onsite and to the public. Advario also continues to improve by implementing an incident investigation database to monitor potential risks of future incidents. The improvements made by Advario , along with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents

.

* Maintenance Procedures - The plant has specific procedures for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.

* Maintenance Training - The plant trains persons who perform routine maintenance tasks on process equipment.

* Mechanical Integrity Program - Storage tanks and piping are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

* Incident Investigation - The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.

* Employee Participation - The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program elements.

* Hot Work Permit - The plant has a procedure to ensure that welding, cutting, and brazing are safely performed in areas where flammables or combustible material may be present.

* Compliance Audits - Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.

* Operational Safety Program - Advario has a comprehensive program to ensure that the elements listed above are implemented at this and other Advario locations. This program includes accountability for timely and proper implementation of the program elements.

These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent accidental chemical releases. Advario and its employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set, and have specific accountability and controls to ensure that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.

Advario complies with the RMP rules and regulations set forth by the EPA and even some elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings. While the VAM is not a PSM chemical and falls under Program 2, other RMP exempt chemicals are onsite that are subject to PSM. 

The Advario  site designed its accident prevention program to comply with both the EPA RMP rules and the relevant portions of OSHA's PSM. Advario incorporates elements addressing the following:

* Equipment Design - Storage tanks and piping are designed in accordance with recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

* Process Safety Information - Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.

* Hazard Review - These reviews are completed to identify major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.

* Episodic Risk Management - Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence. These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.

* Operational Safety Standards - Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in the operational safety standards.

* Operating Procedures - Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.

* Operator Training Program - The plant has a training and testing program, which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.

* Technical Staff Training and Support - Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day to support operations

OFF SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

40 CFR 68 requires all facilities subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions rule to conduct an Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) to provide information to the public as well as state and federal environmental agencies about any potential consequences of an accidental chemical release. OCA's are essential in identifying the potential hazards of an accidental release. OCA's can consist of two elements, a WCS and an ARS, for each type of chemical (either flammable or toxic handled at the facility in a quantity greater than that chemical's threshold as listed in 40 CFR §68.130).

There is one WCS associated with a toxic release of vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) at the facility.  The scenario involves a liquid release involving 10,938,665 pounds of VAM from tank 9702. The entire inventory of this tank is assumed to release and evaporate, impacting an area with a 25-mile radius.

The ARS associated with the VAM tanks involves a piping failure between the tank and the closest valve. The pipe is six (6) inches in diameter and 120 feet in length, which results in 5,530 lbs of liquid VAM being released and then evaporating. This would impact an area with a 0.3-mile radius.  

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Advario took ownership of the VAM tanks on 4/3/2017. There have been no accidents since that time.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

The plans for evacuation and accounting for personnel after an evacuation at the Advario site are located onsite for personnel to review. If a release occurs, arrangements are described in the Emergency Response Plan/Integrated Contingency Plan for notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.

Advario  Galveston County, LLC (Advario ) operates a facility that stores chemicals including 
 specialty polymers, solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products.  Operations occurring at Advario include loading/unloading, storage, transportation, and distribution of chemicals.  U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations presented in Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68), the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, require Advario to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule because the quantities of vinyl acetate monomer stored onsite exceed threshold quantities.

The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA-approved chemical release prevention program. In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP covered facilities to update its Risk Management Program Plan (RMP Plan) within six (6) months of an RMP reportable incident or every five (5) years, whichever comes first.  In accordance with 40 CFR 68, Advario is submitting this initial RMP Plan within six (6) months of taking ownership of the site.

Potential offsite consequences of a hypothetical Worst-Case Scenario (WCS) and Alternative Releases Scenario (ARS) were conducted using the EPA RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis and the RMP*Comp program.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating the worst case and alternative release scenarios.
